00002 #Construct for Multiple Choice.
00003 #Inherits from ChoiceList.pm
00004 #VS 6/16/2000
00005 
00006 
00007 =head1 NAME
00008 
00009 Multiple.pm -- sub-class of ChoiceList that implements a multiple choice question.
00010 
00011 All items accessed by $out=$mc->item($in);
00012 
00013 =head1 SYNOPSIS
00014 
00015 Multiple.pm is intended to be used to create one of two types of multiple choice
00016 questions. The regular multiple choice question is one question followed by a
00017 list of answers, only one of which is correct, printed in a bulleted form with
00018 radio buttons to select the correct answer.  The second type of of multiple choice
00019 question consists of one question followed by several answers bulleted with check
00020 boxes so that more than one answer can be selected if more than one answer exists.
00021 Each student will receive the same set of answers in a mostly random order (some
00022 answers can be forced to be at the end of list of answers, see makeLast() below).
00023 
00024 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00025 
00026 =head2 Variables and methods available to Multiple
00027 
00028 =head3 Variables
00029 
00030     questions           # array of questions as entered using qa()
00031     answers             # array of answers as entered using qa()
00032 
00033     selected_q          # randomly selected subset of "questions"
00034     selected_a          # the answers for the selected questions
00035 
00036     slice               # index used to select specific questions
00037     shuffle             # permutation array which can be applied to slice
00038                         # to shuffle the answers
00039 
00040     inverted_shuffle    # the inverse permutation array
00041 
00042     rf_print_q          # reference to any subroutine which should
00043                         # take ($self, @questions) as parameters and
00044                         # output the questions in a formatted string.
00045                         # If you want to change the way questions are
00046                         # printed, write your own print method and set
00047                         # this equal to a reference to to that method
00048                         # (i.e. $sl->rf_print_q = ~~&printing_routine_q)
00049 
00050     rf_print_a          # reference to any subroutine which should
00051                         # take ($self, @answers) as parameters and
00052                         # output the answers in a formatted string.
00053                         # If you want to change the way answers are
00054                         # printed, write your own print method and set
00055                         # this equal to a reference to to that method
00056                         # (i.e. $sl->rf_print_a = ~~&printing_routine_a)
00057 
00058 =head3 Methods
00059 
00060     qa( array )         # accepts an array of strings which can be used
00061                         # for the question and answers
00062 
00063     extra( array )      # accepts an array of strings which can be used
00064                         # as extra answers
00065 
00066     print_q             # yields a formatted string of question to be
00067                         # matched with answer blanks
00068     print_a             # yields a formatted string of answers
00069 
00070     choose([3, 4], 1)   # chooses questions indexed 3 and 4 and one other
00071                         # randomly
00072     makeLast( array )   # accepts an array of strings (like qa) which will
00073                         # be forced to the end of the list of answers.
00074 
00075     correct_ans         # outputs a reference to the array of correct answers
00076 
00077 
00078 =head2 Usage
00079 
00080 
00081 =head3 Regular Multiple Choice
00082 
00083 Create a multiple choice question using the new_multiple_choice call.
00084 
00085 =for html
00086     <PRE>
00087     <I>$mc = new_multiple_choice</I>
00088     </PRE>
00089 
00090 Use qa() to enter the question and the correct answer. Any duplicates will be eliminated.
00091 
00092 =for html
00093      <PRE>
00094      <I>$mc->qa('\( x^2 \) is:', 'quadratic');</I></PRE>
00095 
00096 After calling qa you can use extra() to add in extra incorrect answers that (along with the
00097 correct answer) will be made into a random list of answers shown to the student.
00098 
00099 =for html
00100     <PRE>
00101     <I>$mc->extra(
00102         'cubic',
00103         'logarithmic',
00104         'exponential'
00105     );</I></PRE>
00106 
00107 
00108 If you want certain answers to be at the end of the list instead of having them be randomized
00109 you can use makeLast to add specific answers to the end of the list of answers or to force
00110 already existing answers to be moved to the end of the list.  This is usually done for
00111 'None of the above', or 'All of the above' type answers.  Note that if 'None of the above'
00112 is the correct answer then you must put it in qa() and then also makeLast() but the duplicate
00113 will be eliminated.  If more than one extra answer is added via makeLast, they are added
00114 in the same order they are given in makeLast.
00115 
00116 =for html
00117     <PRE>
00118     <I>$mc->makeLast(
00119         'All of the above',
00120         'None of the above'
00121     );</I></PRE>
00122 
00123 Now you would start your problem with a C<BEGIN_TEXT> tag and print the questions
00124 and answers with the print_q() and print_a() commands. Within the C<BEGIN_TEXT/END_TEXT block>,
00125 all calls to objects must be enclosed in \( \).
00126 (The $PAR start a new paragraph by printing a blank line).
00127 
00128 =for html
00129     <PRE>
00130     <I>BEGIN_TEXT
00131         $PAR
00132         \{ $mc->print_q() \}
00133         $PAR
00134         \{ $mc->print_a() \}
00135     END_TEXT</I></PRE>
00136 
00137 Now all that''s left is sending the students answers to the answer evaluator
00138 along with the correct answers so that the students answers can be checked and
00139 a score can be given.  This is done using C<ANS>, an answer evaluator and the
00140 C<correct_ans> variable.
00141 
00142 =for html
00143     <PRE>
00144     <I>ANS(radio_cmp($mc->correct_ans))</I></PRE>
00145 
00146 
00147 =head3 Checkbox Multiple Choice
00148 
00149 
00150 A checkbox multiple choice problem is identical to a regular multiple choice problem with only
00151 a few exceptions.
00152 
00153 First, you create the checkbox multiple choice object using the command:
00154 
00155 =for html
00156     <PRE>
00157     <I>$cmc = new_checkbox_multiple_choice</I></PRE>
00158 
00159 Then you would call qa() just as in a regular multiple choice object except that this time
00160 you can provide more than one answer
00161 
00162 =for html
00163      <PRE>
00164      <I>$cmc->qa(
00165                 'Indicate all the functions that are anti-derivatives of \( 3x^2 \)',
00166                 '\( x^3 \)',
00167                 '\( x^3 - 57 \)',
00168                 '\( 27 + x^3 \)'
00169     );</I></PRE>
00170 
00171 Then you would use extra() and makeLast() and create the problem just as with a regular multiple
00172 choice.  The only other difference is that at then end of the problem you would use checkbox_cmp()
00173 instead of radio_cmp().
00174 
00175 =for html
00176     <PRE>
00177     <I>ANS(radio_cmp($cmc->correct_ans))</I></PRE>
00178 
00179 
00180 =cut
00181 
00182 BEGIN {
00183     be_strict();
00184 }
00185 
00186 #use strict;
00187 package Multiple;
00188 
00189 @Multiple::ISA = undef;
00190 @Multiple::ISA = qw( Exporter ChoiceList );
00191 
00192 # *** Subroutines which overload ChoiceList.pm ***
00193 sub choose { warn "Multiple choice does not support choosing answers.\n(You can't use \$mc->choose().)"; }
00194 sub choose_extra { warn "Multiple choice does not support choosing answers.\n(You can't use \$mc->choose_extra().)"; }
00195 sub extras { warn "Extras() is not a method of Multiple.pm.\nUse the extra() method to add extra answers."; }
00196 
00197 sub qa {
00198     my $self = shift;
00199     my @input = @_;
00200 
00201     push( @{ $self->{questions} }, shift(@input) ); #one question
00202     push( @{ $self->{answers} }, @input );  #correct answer(s)
00203 
00204     $self->choose2(scalar(@{ $self->{answers} }));
00205 }
00206 
00207 sub extra {
00208     my $self = shift;
00209     my @input = @_;
00210 
00211     push( @{ $self->{extras} }, @input);
00212 
00213     #call as a method of $self
00214     &ChoiceList::choose_extra($self, scalar(@{ $self->{extras} }));
00215 }
00216 
00217 #This means rf_print_q is not used but still exists for user customization
00218 sub print_q {
00219     my $self = shift;
00220 
00221     @{ $self->{questions} }[0];
00222 }
00223 
00224 
00225 #This is called choose2 because it needs to be called internally
00226 #but i didn't want it available to the user (hence choose being
00227 #overloaded to give a error message above).
00228 sub choose2 {
00229     my $self = shift;
00230     my @input = @_;
00231 
00232     $self->getRandoms(scalar(@{ $self->{answers} }), @input);
00233     $self->selectQA();
00234 }
00235 
00236 sub selectQA {
00237     my $self = shift;
00238 
00239     $self->{selected_q} = $self->{questions};
00240     $self->{selected_a} = [ @{ $self->{answers} }[@{ $self->{shuffle} }] ];
00241     $self->{inverted_shuffle} = [ &ChoiceList::invert(@{ $self->{shuffle} }) ];
00242 }
00243 
00244 #Multiple
00245 sub ra_correct_ans {
00246     warn "Multiple does not use ra_correct_ans because radio_cmp and checkbox_cmp expect a string.\nYou should use correct_ans instead.";
00247 }
00248 
00249 #sends letters for comparison instead of actual answers
00250 #actual answers aren't used because they might contain LaTeX or HTML
00251 sub correct_ans {
00252     my $self = shift;
00253     my @ans = &ChoiceList::ALPHABET( sort { $a <=> $b } @{$self->{inverted_shuffle}} );
00254 
00255     #radio_cmp and checkbox_cmp expect a string, not a reference to an array like str_cmp, etc
00256     join "", @ans;
00257 }
00258 
00259 1;
